Kural_Info.Tamil_Text: உண்ணாமை உள்ளது உயிர்நிலை ஊனுண்ணஅண்ணாத்தல் செய்யாது அளறு.
Kural_Info.English_Meaning: Not to eat flesh contributes to the continuance of life; therefore if a man eat flesh, hell will not open its mouth (to let him escape out, after he has once fallen in).

Layered_Composition.Midground: On the right, a person is shown abstaining from eating flesh ('உண்ணாமை'). This act is shown to support and strengthen the state of life; a great, healthy, flourishing tree of life ('உயிர் நிலை') grows beside them.
Layered_Composition.Background: On the left, a person is shown eating flesh ('ஊன் உண்ண'). As they do so, a terrifying, monstrous, living Hell-mouth ('அளறு') opens in the ground beneath them and swallows them. The mouth of Hell is shown to be a one-way gate; it does not open again to let them out ('அண்ணாத்தல் செய்யாது').

Art_Direction.Subject_and_Action: Abstaining from flesh-eating supports life. Indulging in it leads to a one-way trip to a hell that will not release its victims.
Art_Direction.Symbolic_Motifs: The Tree of Life versus the consuming Hell-mouth is a stark and powerful contrast. The one-way nature of the Hell-mouth—it swallows but does not spit out—is the key terrifying element.
Art_Direction.Mood_and_Emotion: Life vs. eternal damnation, horrifying, inescapable doom.
Art_Direction.Lighting_and_Color: The right side is bathed in the warm, vibrant, life-giving light of the Tree of Life. The left side is lit by the terrifying, hellish, red and orange glow from within the monstrous Hell-mouth.

Technical_Cues.Camera: A dramatic diptych showing the two opposing fates.
Technical_Cues.Resolution: 8K, hyper-realistic, with a beautiful design for the Tree of Life and a terrifying, grotesque design for the living Hell-mouth.
Technical_Cues.Lighting: Strong dualistic lighting: one side heavenly, the other hellish.
Technical_Cues.Art_Genre: Epic dark fantasy, with mythological elements.
